On Mon, 17 May 2004 19:22:51 -0000, Kenneth Stanley
<kstanley@...> wrote:
> 
> Derek,
> 
> This doesn't directly address your questions but have you checkout
> out the Pareto Coevolution stuff from Pollack's group.  Their
> complete paper list is here:
> 
> http://helen.cs-i.brandeis.edu/papers/
> 
> But the stuff on Pareto coevolution can give you a lot of insight
> into what coevolution is really trying to do and what it needs to do
> it.

Thanks, Ken.  I've looked at a bit of the Pareto Coevolution stuff,
and we've discussed it a bit on the list...a long while back, I think.
 But from what I understand, current methods of pareto coevolution are
very computationally expensive, and are intractable in all but trivial
domains.  But I get you're point about looking into the research to
understand coevolutionary concepts.

Along these lines, I like the idea of "speciated sampling", though I
don't think you gave it a name.  You used this technique in the JAIR
paper, correct?  Sampling evenly from species, rather than randomly
from the population as a whole?

Derek
